topic: Arts and Culture in the UK

questions.question: What is The Proms?
questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of classical orchestral music organised by the BBC.

questions.question: Which organisation has organised The Proms since 1927?
questions.explanation: The BBC has organised The Proms since 1927.

questions.question: Where is the Last Night of the Proms held?
questions.explanation: The Last Night of the Proms takes place at the Royal Albert Hall in London.

questions.question: Who wrote Water Music and Music for the Royal Fireworks?
questions.explanation: George Frederick Handel composed both Water Music and Music for the Royal Fireworks.

questions.question: When did Handel become a British citizen?
questions.explanation: Handel became a British citizen in 1727.

questions.question: Who composed The Planets?
questions.explanation: Gustav Holst composed The Planets suite.

questions.question: Which hymn uses a tune from Holst’s The Planets?
choices: I Vow to Thee My Country
questions.explanation: Holst adapted Jupiter from The Planets into the hymn I Vow to Thee My Country.

questions.question: Which composer wrote the Pomp and Circumstance Marches?
questions.explanation: Sir Edward Elgar composed the Pomp and Circumstance Marches.

questions.question: What piece is usually played at the Last Night of the Proms?
questions.explanation: Land of Hope and Glory, from Elgar’s March No. 1, is played at the Last Night of the Proms.

questions.question: Who founded the Aldeburgh Festival?
questions.explanation: Benjamin Britten founded the Aldeburgh Festival in Suffolk.

questions.question: Which band was NOT from the 1960s British pop era?
questions.explanation: The Sex Pistols were part of the later 1970s punk movement.

questions.question: What is the National Eisteddfod of Wales?
questions.explanation: The National Eisteddfod of Wales is an annual cultural festival featuring music, dance, and poetry.

questions.question: Which award celebrates the best album from the UK and Ireland?
questions.explanation: The Mercury Prize honours the best album from the UK and Ireland.

questions.question: What is the longest-running show in West End history?
questions.explanation: Agatha Christie’s The Mousetrap has been running since 1952.

questions.question: Who wrote The Pirates of Penzance?
questions.explanation: Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas including The Pirates of Penzance.

questions.question: Which festival is known for experimental theatre and comedy?
questions.explanation: The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is famous for experimental theatre and comedy.

questions.question: Who are the Laurence Olivier Awards named after?
questions.explanation: The awards are named after actor Sir Laurence (Lord) Olivier.

questions.question: Which artist is linked to the Pop Art movement?
questions.explanation: David Hockney was a leading figure in the Pop Art movement of the 1960s.

questions.question: What is the Turner Prize awarded for?
questions.explanation: The Turner Prize celebrates achievements in contemporary art.

questions.question: Which gallery hosts the Turner Prize exhibitions?
questions.explanation: The Turner Prize finalists’ works are displayed at Tate Britain.
